A RUSHWORTH man has been fined $1322 for illegally felling trees in the Redcastle - Greytown State Forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Rushworth Workcentre operations coordinator Josh Mabon said the man cut and removed dead standing trees on two separate occasions.

Mr Mabon said officers had issued the 36-year-old man with an infringement notice for each time he cut and removed a tree from the forest.

urn:contentItem:61T1-BH01-F0J6-J06W-00000-00Safety call for park patrons2021-01-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Safety call for park patronsElspeth Kernebone

USE common sense is the message for Victorians planning to visit the state's parks, forests and reserves during the Australia day long weekend. Prospective visitors have been urged to not light a campfire in hot, windy weather, or litter. Forest Fire Management said anyone who did light a campfire should make sure it was fully extinguished and watch for embers.

FFMVic said anyone who saw illegal behaviour should report it on 136 186. Monitor conditions at: emergency.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:63CX-4VT1-JD3N-50VT-00000-00Extreme fire danger to double2021-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Extreme fire danger to doubleOLIVIA JENKINS

FIREFIGHTERS could be -battling to contain Black -Saturday-like bushfires across Victoria every six months by the end of the century if temperatures continue to rise.

New research conducted by the Country Fire Authority (CFA) with Monash University found man-made pollution will cause the number of extreme fire danger days in Victoria to -double over the next 80 years.

CFA research manager and study co-author Sarah Harris said Victoria's fire season would become longer and more dangerous without drastic intervention to drive temperatures down.

"There is likely to be a 10 to 20 per cent increase in fire weather across the state," Dr Harris said.

"Temperature changes are the greatest driver of fire weather changes," she said. The report revealed rising surface temperatures and stronger dry cold fronts could ignite savage blazes such as the 2009 Black Saturday tragedy and the 1983 Ash Wednesday Fires up to twice a year by 2100. Projections also indicated a 10 to 20 per cent jump in -extreme forest fire danger in the state's northwest and east.

urn:contentItem:63KW-B0R1-F0JP-W1YJ-00000-00One tree on fire led to tragedy2021-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10One tree on fire led to tragedyLane Sainty

A SINGLE burning tree believed to be the origin of a devastating south coast bushfire was spotted from the air hours after its likely ignition from a lightning strike, a court has been told.

But the Black Summer blaze started in such a remote -location crews had to wait for it to spread before they could -attempt to extinguish it.

The Werri Berri bushfire went on to ravage more than 27,000ha of bushland near the town of Bemboka, NSW, destroying 24 homes as it burned for almost a month before merging with the deadly Badja Forest fire.

It is among the fires and tragic deaths being investigated by state coroner Teresa O'Sullivan as part of the NSW bushfire inquiry.

A Rural Fire Service helicopter crew was scrutinising the Tuross Valley for spot fires on the afternoon of December 29, 2019, when crewman Jake Roarty spotted a plume of smoke rising from the bush at about 5pm. Mr Roarty told the NSW Coroners Court on Monday that he was "confident" the smoke was coming from a single tree that was alight with flames.

urn:contentItem:61K8-4J41-F0J6-J1NP-00000-00Agency battles growth2020-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Agency battles growthElspeth Kernebone

FIRE protection works are continuing across 2000 hectares of public land in central Victoria, as agencies battle rapid grass growth.

The Forest Fire Management Victoria preparations across the Murray Goldfields District include slashing and moving public land. FFMVic district manager Adrian Parker said recent spring rain had caused quick grass growth throughout the area.

Mr Parker said works would continue this week near Bendigo, Huntly, Flora Hill, Golden Square, Ironbark, Castlemaine and Macedon.

urn:contentItem:5Y6F-X3K1-DY17-M293-00000-00Pialligo photos: taking the fight to the fire2020-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisPialligo photos: taking the fight to the fire

The January 22 Pialligo fire. Photo: Andrew Campbell.

MASTER snapper ANDREW CAMPBELL shot afternoon and night photos of the Pialligo Redwood Forest fire yesterday (January 22) which was MASTER snapper ANDREW CAMPBELL shot afternoon and night photos of the Pialligo Redwood Forest fire yesterday (January 22) which was At its start, the fire was rated as an "emergency" and people in the suburbs of Oaks Estate, Beard and West Queanbeyan were told it was too late to flee. By mid evening it had been downgraded and the ESA said it was under control. Photographer Campbell took the afternoon photos from Mount Ainslie. The photos of the fire and helicopters are from the back of Fyshwick. "The night ones were 2am, shot from the side of Pialligo Avenue looking south, just past the airport on the way to Queanbeyan," he says. "I especially like the fire truck driving slowly through the remnants of the fire."

urn:contentItem:623N-NPS1-F0JP-W0Y8-00000-00Planned burn in Otways2021-02-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Planned burn in Otways

SMOKE and flames will be visible along the Great Ocean Road as firefighters undertake a 310-hectare planned burn near Lorne.

More than 100 firefighters from Forest Fire Management Victoria as well as several aircraft and heavy machinery will be involved in the five-day operation across Great Otway National Park and private property, which began on Saturday.

Sections of walking tracks will be closed including She-oak Picnic Ground, the Allenvale Campground and Phantom Falls. Incident controller Stephanie Ryan said the burn would reduce the amount of bushfire fuel to reduce the intensity of potential bushfires approaching Lorne from the southwest.

urn:contentItem:6376-PVS1-JD3N-51W1-00000-00Call for input on bike trails2021-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Call for input on bike trailsSimone Kealy

FOREST Fire Management Victoria is seeking community input as part of the Forrest Trailhead precinct upgrade set to start this year.

The redesign wants to see Forrest become a leading mountain biking destination as part of a $2.32m upgrade of mountain bike trails. FFMVic has released a community survey on the redesign, as well as the new skills park, signs and facilities such as showers, a bike wash and barbecues.

FFMVic Otway district manager David Roberts said he encouraged everyone to have their say on the precinct.

"We're aiming to deliver improvements and new facilities that will create an engaging natural environment for visitors and locals," he said.

Colac Otway Shire Council Mayor Kate Hanson said the upgrade would be a welcome boost for Forrest.

"(We're excited about) seeing (the precinct) become a vibrant gateway to the trail network, attracting more visitors to Colac Otway and supporting local business," she said. The survey closes on August 18 and can be accessed at engage.vic.gov.au/upgrading-forrest-mountain-bike-mtb-trailhead.

urn:contentItem:5YG6-9351-JD34-V3VF-00000-00Planned burn set for Heathcote this weekend2020-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEPlanned burn set for Heathcote this weekendChris Pedler

Planned burns near Heathcote will be conducted by Forest Fire Management Victoria if conditions suit.

The 142 hectare burn will be about one kilometre north of Heathcote and aims to reduce the potential impact of bushfires on communities and the environment.

FFMVic acting regional manager forest fire operations Paul Bates said planned burning was part of an integrated strategic approach to protecting life and property from the risk of bushfire.

"If conditions are suitable, residents in Heathcote and surrounding areas may see or smell smoke from the ignition of a planned burn in the McIvor Ranges this weekend," he said.

"Our crews follow careful processes before, during and after a burn, to make sure it is kept safe and controlled.

"Our crews will use a range of equipment to complete the two-day burn including hand-held drip torches for ignition, 4-wheel drive ultralight tankers, large fire tankers and a bulldozer."

For details on when and where planned burns are visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:63JT-G5R1-JD3N-526C-00000-00Bushfire inquiry hears of selfless act, tragic call2021-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Bushfire inquiry hears of selfless act, tragic callHeath Parkes-Hupton

AN inquest has been told how an elderly man spent the early hours of New Year's Eve waking up neighbours as a fire approached their homes.

Weeks later, another victim of the Black Summer bushfires told his brother "I've gotta get back out there" in what would be the last words he was ever heard to say.

The deaths of Ross Rixon and Michael Clarke were explored on Wednesday before the Lidcombe Coroners Court.

Mr Rixon, who was 84, roused neighbours from their sleep as the deadly Badja Forest fire bore down on them on December 31, 2019. Remembered as a "tough old bastard", he suffered serious burns trying to save his Cobargo home.

Mr Rixon died of a heart -attack at Concord Hospital on January 18, 2020, after he was transferred there for treatment on his injuries.

Earlier, the court heard about the final words Bodalla man Mr Clarke was heard to say on January 23, 2020. Mr Clarke, 59, died taking cover inside his Bombo Rd farmhouse. At 2.40pm, he spoke to his brother Shane on the phone. "The shed just lit up," he told his brother. "I gotta get back out there." It would be their last -conversation.

urn:contentItem:61C9-1P41-JD34-V509-00000-00Fuel reduction burn due to begin2020-11-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Fuel reduction burn due to begin

A 174-hectare fuel reduction burn is scheduled to start near Bendigo today. Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA will carry out the planned burn on Carcoola Drive, in the Kangaroo Flat area. It should be completed by the evening of next Wednesday, although smoke could remain visible for another week after that. Anyone experiencing symptoms that could be the result of smoke exposure should seek medical attention or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

urn:contentItem:61C3-2KX1-F0J6-J23N-00000-00Campfires: reminder of big fines2020-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisCampfires: reminder of big finesSophie Boyd

Firefighters have issued a warning to residents and visitors after multiple unattended campfires were found in North East Victoria.

From Friday November 12 to Sunday, 12 campfires were found unattended.

Forest Fire Management Victoria warned campfire negligence causes about 10 per cent of all Victorian bushfires. On-the-spot fines of $496 can be issued to people breaching campfire safety rules and the maximum penalty for lighting a fire during a total fire ban is $39,652, two years in jail, or both.

urn:contentItem:5XYG-3G71-DXX7-H1G6-00000-00Victorian firefighter dies near Omeo as Australia's fires crisis continues2020-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisVictorian firefighter dies near Omeo as Australia's fires crisis continues

A Victorian firefighter has died while working on a blaze near Omeo.

Chris Hardman, chief fire officer at Forest Fire Management Victoria, said the firefighter was involved in an incident while working in the area around the East Gippsland town.

"Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Mr Hardman said.

"The safety and wellbeing of our people is our highest priority."

Victoria Police will investigate the matter and prepare a report for the coroner.

It takes the state's bushfire death toll to four, including Mat Kavanagh, another Forest Fire Management Victoria employee who was killed in a road crash last Friday.

"On that day he had extinguished seven unattended campfires. He was doing incredibly critical work," Mr Hardman said at the time.

Buchan man Mick Roberts was the first victim of the bushfire emergency, while Maramingo Creek timber worker Fred Becker was confirmed dead at the weekend.

urn:contentItem:5YF4-F021-JD34-V3HJ-00000-00More planned burns to take place near Talbot, Castlemaine2020-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisMore planned burns to take place near Talbot, Castlemaine

FOREST Fire Management and the Country Fire Authority will conduct two planned burns near Talbot and Castlemaine from Monday.

About 227 hectares will be burned 3.4 kilometres north of Talbot along the Amherst-Four Cat Track. A further 47 hectares will be burned 3.6 kilometres north of Castlemaine on the Walmer Reillys Track.

The burns will start at 10am on Monday and are expected to last through to 8pm on Friday.

Read more: Planned burn to take place at Mount Hooghly, near Dunolly: Forest Fire Management, CFA

Residents near Talbot, Amherst, Castlemaine, Barkers Creek, Walmer, and Harcourt may see smoke until March 27.

Authorities are advising some roads may be hazardous due to low viability associated with smoke. Signs may also be in place to slow traffic.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites may also be restricted.

More information about planned burns can be found at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

Firefighters have issued a warning to residents and visitors after multiple unattended campfires were found in North East Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria warned campfire negligence causes about 10 per cent of all Victorian bushfires. urn:contentItem:5Y92-9XK1-F0JP-W1KT-00000-00State fuel-load maps remain a secret2020-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20State fuel-load maps remain a secretBy PETER HUNT

THE Andrews Government is justifying its refusal to release damming fuel load maps on the advice of the man responsible for running fuel reduction burns, Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman.

The only map released to The Weekly Times last year, shows in the lead-up to this fire season highly flammable fuel loads had built up to extreme levels in Victoria's most populous and dangerous East Central zone, which bore the brunt of the 2009 Black Saturday deaths and property damage.

But in responding to a motion from Parliament's Upper House that the maps be released Attorney-General Jill Hennessy stated the Government was claiming "executive privilege" and their release was not in the public interest.

"The public interest exception is based on the expert opinion of the Chief Fire Officer of Forest Fire Management Victoria that the disclosure of the relevant maps would prejudice public safety at this time," Ms Hennessy told the Upper House.Premier Daniel Andrews, Upper House leader Gavin Jennings and Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville have all stated the maps could be used by arsonists, a claim leading bushfire scientists have labelled "ludicrous".

urn:contentItem:62MN-W051-JD34-V068-00000-00Traditional burn set for Arapiles2021-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Traditional burn set for Arapiles

Forest Fire Management is carrying out a planned burn in Arapiles.

The burn will use traditional owners' techniques to provide conditions for the doubling of native grass densities in the area.

The planned burns began on Saturday, May 7, are scheduled to conclude on Wednesday, July 14.

The burns will only take place between 12-8pm.

Smoke may be visible from Mount Arapiles Tooan State Park and Two Mile Creek Frontage.

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.

Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

For travel times and roadworks checks, visit http://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:6242-TJ11-F0JP-W29D-00000-00Weekend Lorne burn2021-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Weekend Lorne burn

FOREST Fire Management Victoria completed a 310-hectare planned burn near Lorne at the weekend.

The operation was carried out across the Great Otway National Park and private property to reduce bushfire fuel and reduce the bushfire risk for Lorne.

The five-day operation included burning on clifftops above the Great Ocean Road and created a large column of smoke.

Lorne and surrounding communities will continue to see smoke, and crews will remain on site over the coming days to patrol the burn area until it's safe.

Part of Lorne's walking track network remains closed, including Sheoak Picnic Ground, Allenvale Campground and Phantom Falls. To find out when and where planned burns are happening, visit vic.gov.au/plannedburns or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:6142-1HM1-F0J6-J3JS-00000-00Bushfire prep is sparked2020-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Bushfire prep is sparked

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has hired 55 fixed-term firefighters to bulk up for summer. The extra firefighters will begin across the Murray Goldfields district - which encompasses Bendigo - later this month. FFMVic will also put specialists on standby at incident control centres at Epsom and Gisborne from as early as next month. The teams will be able to respond 24-hours a day during the bushfire season. Two fire-fighting helicopters will return to the Bendigo airbase in summer.

urn:contentItem:6263-VDT1-JD34-V0HC-00000-00Fire base upgrade opens in region2021-03-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisFire base upgrade opens in regionVivienne Jones

A new $10.3 million office and depot aimed at increasing fire response and management in the Upper Murray was opened in Tallangatta yesterday.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's new facility will increase Forest Fire Management Victoria's capacity to respond to and manage bushfires and other emergencies in the region and was officially opened by state Environment Minister Lily D'Ambrosio.

The site on the corner of the Murray Valley Highway and Tallangatta Lookout Road will accommodate 19 office staff and a further 18 fire operations officers, and seasonal project firefighters.

"Upper Murray communities were significantly impacted during the 2019/20 bushfire season, so this new facility will help to support bushfire response and recovery works into the future," Ms D'Ambrosio said.

The project included the construction of new depot sheds and infrastructure, a modern office facility and an Incident Control Centre.

urn:contentItem:60P9-PM81-JD34-V3D8-00000-00Officials plan burn in Hunter2020-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:54ZLexisNexisOfficials plan burn in Hunter

FOREST Fire Management and the Country Fire Authority say there will be a planned burn near Elmore from Friday. About four hectares will be burned at the Hunter Elmore-Cohuna rail line bushland reserve in Hunter. The Dja Dja Wurrung will start the cultural burn at 10am on Friday, if weather permits. The burn is expected to last until 8pm on Monday. Residents in Hunter, Drummartin, and Elmore may see smoke from the burn until Wednesday. For more information, visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au
